citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
During inspection, the following were found:
- In an enclosure containing 5 “Skinny Guinea Pigs”, 3 of the animals contained skin lesions. A black and white guinea
pig, the smallest in the enclosure, had a large number of white lines carved in his skin covering his entire back, neck and
both sides. Several sections of crusty black raised scabs could also be seen associated with scratches throughout. A pink
guinea pig contained three small circular lesions that were slightly reddened, raised, and flaking. One in the middle of his
lower back, one over his left leg and another in the left posterior area. A grey guinea pig contained a moderate amount of
scratches with crusty red/black scabs across the top of his back and right side with some fresh blood noted in some of the
lesions.
- In an enclosure housing 17 male hedgehogs, 6 had lesions on their ears. Two had a swollen right ear with black raised
crusty material around the edges as well as small open wounds and reddened skin. Two had a moderate amount of thick,
crusty black material at the tip of an ear (left ear for one, right for the other) with some reddened mildly ulcerated skin
beneath. One had thick black crusty material covering a large portion of both ears with reddened skin beneath. One had
his right ear made up of an ulcerated bleeding lesion with a moderate amount of thick crusty black material to the side.
-In an enclosure housing 20 parakeets, 6 parakeets contained approximately dime sized circular areas of feather loss at
the base of their tails with some scabbing, with little to no feather regrowth and 2 were seen actively itching at the base of
their tails.
All animals identified were in otherwise good health and did not show signs of discomfort. However, these conditions were
not identified by the licensee, therefore care had not been initiated. Failure to promptly identify such conditions delays
care and may result in undue discomfort. A more rigorous method of daily observation of all animals must be implemented
in order to properly assess their health and well-being. Correct by November 29, 2023.

A large grey bin storing a large pile of ready to use food receptacles contained a large amount of bedding, and tiny brown
debris, as well as crinkle enrichment paper dispersed throughout the bottom. A substantial amount of cockroaches were
seen at the bottom of the bin running amongst the ready to use food receptacles. With such storage conditions, the food
receptacles could become contaminated which could result in the transfer of disease to the animals. Correct by keeping
the premises, including storage areas, clean and free of accumulation of trash to prevent the harboring of pests thus
protecting the animals. Correct by November 27, 2023.

citations.desc: Primary enclosures used to transport live guinea pigs and hamsters.
citations.narrative:
Multiple large blue tub transport containers that contained live guinea pigs and hamsters did not contain the words “Live
Animals” and did not contain arrows/markings to indicate the correct upright position of the container. Lack of markings
may lead to mishandling of the enclosures which may lead to injury and stress to the animals. All guinea pig and hamster
enclosures shall be marked on top and at least one side with the words ``Live Animals'' in letters not less than 2.5
centimeters (1 inch) in height, and with arrows or other markings, to indicate the correct upright position of the container.
Correct by December 4, 2023.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
Additional Inspectors:
STEPHANIE MAYARD, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.40(b)(3) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
During inspection, the following were found: 
- In an enclosure containing 5 “Skinny Guinea Pigs”, 3 of the animals contained skin lesions. A black and white guinea 
pig, the smallest in the enclosure, had a large number of white lines carved in his skin covering his entire back, neck and 
both sides. Several sections of crusty black raised scabs could also be seen associated with scratches throughout. A pink 
guinea pig contained three small circular lesions that were slightly reddened, raised, and flaking. One in the middle of his 
lower back, one over his left leg and another in the left posterior area. A grey guinea pig contained a moderate amount of 
scratches with crusty red/black scabs across the top of his back and right side with some fresh blood noted in some of the 
lesions. 
- In an enclosure housing 17 male hedgehogs, 6 had lesions on their ears. Two had a swollen right ear with black raised 
crusty material around the edges as well as small open wounds and reddened skin. Two had a moderate amount of thick, 
crusty black material at the tip of an ear (left ear for one, right for the other) with some reddened mildly ulcerated skin 
beneath. One had thick black crusty material covering a large portion of both ears with reddened skin beneath. One had 
his right ear made up of an ulcerated bleeding lesion with a moderate amount of thick crusty black material to the side. 
-In an enclosure housing 20 parakeets, 6 parakeets contained approximately dime sized circular areas of feather loss at 
the base of their tails with some scabbing, with little to no feather regrowth and 2 were seen actively itching at the base of 
their tails. 
All animals identified were in otherwise good health and did not show signs of discomfort. However, these conditions were 
not identified by the licensee, therefore care had not been initiated. Failure to promptly identify such conditions delays 
care and may result in undue discomfort. A more rigorous method of daily observation of all animals must be implemented 
in order to properly assess their health and well-being. Correct by November 29, 2023. 
3.31(b) 
   
Sanitation. 
A large grey bin storing a large pile of ready to use food receptacles contained a large amount of bedding, and tiny brown 
debris, as well as crinkle enrichment paper dispersed throughout the bottom. A substantial amount of cockroaches were 
seen at the bottom of the bin running amongst the ready to use food receptacles. With such storage conditions, the food 
receptacles could become contaminated which could result in the transfer of disease to the animals. Correct by keeping

the premises, including storage areas, clean and free of accumulation of trash to prevent the harboring of pests thus 
protecting the animals. Correct by November 27, 2023. 
3.36(g) 
   
Primary enclosures used to transport live guinea pigs and hamsters. 
Multiple large blue tub transport containers that contained live guinea pigs and hamsters did not contain the words “Live 
Animals” and did not contain arrows/markings to indicate the correct upright position of the container. Lack of markings 
may lead to mishandling of the enclosures which may lead to injury and stress to the animals. All guinea pig and hamster 
enclosures shall be marked on top and at least one side with the words ``Live Animals'' in letters not less than 2.5 
centimeters (1 inch) in height, and with arrows or other markings, to indicate the correct upright position of the container. 
Correct by December 4, 2023. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
STEPHANIE MAYARD, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
